Chief complaint.Description: I feel overwhelmingly sad and have no energy to do anything.

Symptom.Name: Persistent sadness
Symptom.Triggering factor: Increased workload and stress at work

Family history.Diagnosis: Mother diagnosed with major depressive disorder
Family history.Substance use: Father had a history of alcohol use disorder

Childhood history.Social environment: Had a few close friends, mostly kept to herself

Developmental/social history.Work history: Works as an office worker, good performance, switched jobs twice due to better opportunities, good relationship with supervisor, mixed relations with coworkers

MFC-History:
I grew up in a small town with my parents and a younger brother. My parents were supportive but strict, often emphasizing academic success. In school, I struggled to keep up with my classmates and usually ranked in the lower half of the class, which made me feel insecure about my abilities. I had a few close friends but tended to keep to myself, spending most of my free time reading or listening to music.

As an adult, I started working as an office worker and gradually took on more responsibilities. Although my performance improved and I sometimes received praise from my supervisor, I always felt that I was barely keeping things together. Over the past several months, my workload increased significantly, with frequent deadlines and long hours. Around this time, I began to feel persistently sad and exhausted, losing interest in activities I used to enjoy. I often came home from work and went straight to bed, unable to find the energy to interact with my family.

Recently, these feelings intensified. I started to believe that I was a burden to my family and colleagues, and my sleep and appetite became disturbed. After a particularly stressful week at work, I experienced a crisis point where I seriously considered harming myself. My family noticed the change in my behavior and urged me to seek help, which led me to visit the hospital.

MFC-Behavior.General appearance/attitude/behavior: The patient is a man in his late 40s, appearing appropriate for his age, with a height of approximately 170 cm and a slim build. He has unkempt hair, appearing as though it hasn’t been washed for 2-3 days, a cast on his left arm, furrowed brows, tightly closed lips, and a drooping mouth, giving him a tired appearance. His hygiene seemed somewhat poor, as evidenced by his dirty and untrimmed nails, and his nutritional status also appeared poor, given his dull skin condition. During the interview, his eye contact was poor, as he would briefly look at the interviewer before quickly looking at the floor again. Despite being slow, he answered the questions as sincerely and politely as possible, showing a submissive, attentive, and cooperative attitude. The patient mainly stayed in bed in the ward, showing decreased general activity, and no psychomotor agitation or retardation was observed. Tremor, rigidity, gait disturbance, and other abnormal involuntary movements were not observed.
MFC-Behavior.Mood: Depressed "I feel completely drained, like everything is bleak."
MFC-Behavior.Affect: Restricted, anxious, slightly tense, not labile, not shallow, not inadequate, not inappropriate
MFC-Behavior.Insight: Awareness of being sick but blaming it on others, on external factors, or on organic factors. "The pressure at work was too much for me to bear. Will I get better if I receive treatment?"
MFC-Behavior.Thought content: Preoccupation (+) "I feel like I’m a burden to my company and family because of my shortcomings."

Chief complaint.Description: I feel exhausted and have lost interest in everything I used to enjoy.

Family history.Substance use: Brother had a history of cannabis use

Childhood history.Members of family: Parents, one sister, and one brother
Childhood history.Social environment: Had several friends but felt misunderstood

Developmental/social history.Work history: Works as a teacher, generally good performance, changed schools twice due to relocation, good relationship with students, mixed relations with colleagues

MFC-History:
I grew up in a small town with my parents, an older sister, and a younger brother. Our home was stable in terms of material needs, but emotionally, it always felt like something was missing. My parents were kind yet distant, often preoccupied with their own issues, and though we lived under the same roof, I always felt a degree of separation from them. I remember being a child who had a few friends, but I often felt misunderstood, like there was an invisible barrier between me and the world.

Academically, school was a challenge. I struggled with my studies and usually had low grades, which only added to my feelings of inadequacy. Teachers often described me as quiet and reserved, and while I had a few friends, I never quite felt like I belonged. My brother went through a rough patch during his teenage years and got involved with cannabis, which caused some tension at home. My sister, on the other hand, was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder, and seeing her struggle sometimes made me feel anxious about my own mental health.

As I grew older, I decided to become a teacher, driven by the desire to make a difference in children's lives. Over the years, I have changed schools twice, mainly due to relocations, but I've always maintained a good rapport with my students. They bring a sense of joy and purpose to my life. However, my relationships with colleagues have been mixed; some are supportive, while others make me feel isolated.

The past few months have been particularly tough. After my recent divorce, I found myself engulfed in a wave of exhaustion and disinterest, a stark contrast to the passion I once had for teaching and life in general. My workload increased significantly, and the pressure was overwhelming. Crowded environments now exacerbate my anxiety, making it difficult to perform simple tasks like grocery shopping or attending school events. I find solace in taking short walks, which help clear my mind, albeit temporarily.

These feelings of hopelessness have been persistent, and there are days when I question my worth. While I've never formulated a plan, the idea of escape has crossed my mind more than once, which terrifies me. My migraines, which I've managed well with Sumatriptan over the years, occasionally add to my discomfort with bouts of dizziness. It's all been quite overwhelming, but I'm trying to hold on, seeking the light at the end of this dark tunnel. I know I need help, and I'm ready to take the steps necessary to find myself again.

MFC-Behavior.General appearance/attitude/behavior: The patient is a woman in her early 40s, appearing slightly older due to her tired demeanor. She has a medium build, dressed in simple clothing, which is clean but lacks attention to style. Her hair is neatly tied back, but her eyes show signs of fatigue. Eye contact is sporadic, as she often looks down or away. The patient's posture is hunched, and her movements are slow and deliberate. She presents as cooperative but seems hesitant at times, showing signs of mild psychomotor retardation. There are no abnormal involuntary movements observed.
MFC-Behavior.Mood: Depressed "I feel exhausted and have lost interest in everything I used to enjoy."
MFC-Behavior.Affect: Restricted, tense, and not labile, somewhat flat but appropriate to the context, not inappropriate or inadequate.
MFC-Behavior.Insight: Partial "I know I'm not well, but it's hard to see how things can improve with all that's happened."
MFC-Behavior.Thought content: Preoccupation with feelings of inadequacy and loss "I sometimes feel like I'm failing my students and myself."
